This expertise is critical in parsing the complex legal maneuvers and ongoing litigation around Alina Habba's disputed tenure, the intricate interplay between presidential authority, Senate consent, district court powers, and the limits of the Federal Vacancies Reform Act (FVRA), as well as the likely outcomes of appellate review when the legal authority for an appointment is challenged.

The district court’s ruling is based on clear statutory time limits and longstanding Appointments Clause doctrine, with the FVRA workarounds already rejected as inconsistent with congressional intent. The paralysis in New Jersey federal prosecutions is unsustainable, and the Third Circuit is moving quickly. Historically, once a court has ruled an appointment unlawful, the executive almost always yields within months, especially when criminal justice is at risk. However, the strong political will of the administration, continued website control, and potential for Supreme Court intervention introduce some residual uncertainty. Weighing these, the base rate and legal analysis strongly favor a ‘No’ outcome, but not with absolute certainty due to the administration’s recalcitrance and the specific resolution criteria. I assess the probability that Alina Habba is still the U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey on December 31, 2025 at 17%.

question_details.title: Will Alina Habba still be the U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey on December 31, 2025?
question_details.description:
[Alina Habba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alina_Habba) is a New Jersey lawyer who first came to prominence as a lawyer for then-former President Donald Trump in [2021](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-lawsuit-new-york-times-alina-habba/2021/09/22/8acaf1c2-1bce-11ec-a99a-5fea2b2da34b_story.html). On March 24, 2025, after Trump retook the presidency, he [nominated Habba](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/24/nyregion/trump-alina-habba-new-jersey-us-attorney.html) to serve as the Interim U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey, replacing John Giordano, who had previously been named the Interim U.S. Attorney on March 3, 2025.

Under [federal law](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/28/546), Interim U.S. Attorneys may serve for only 120 days, unless they are confirmed as the U.S. Attorney by the Senate. Once the 120-day period expires, it falls to the local federal district court to appoint someone to the office. In Habba's case, the Senate did not vote on her nomination, and, on July 22, 2025, the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey [announced](https://www.njd.uscourts.gov/sites/njd/files/StandingOrder2025-03USAttyAppointment.pdf) that, upon the expiration of her term, Habba would be replaced by [Desiree Leigh Grace](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/22/nyregion/desiree-grace-new-jersey-us-attorney.html), a longtime prosecutor in the U.S. Attorney's Office.

Grace's tenure would be short-lived. Within days of the court's decision, Attorney General Pam Bondi announced that [Grace had been fired](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/u-s-attorney-new-jersey-alina-habba-desiree-leigh-grace-pam-bondi/) and Habba re-installed, now as the Acting U.S. Attorney. At this time, President Trump also withdrew Habba's nomination to serve as the U.S. Attorney, so that she would be [statutorily eligible](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/5/3345) to serve in the "acting" role.

Federal criminal defendants in New Jersey soon got wise to the situation and began filing motions to dismiss the charges against them, on the basis that Habba's appointment was unlawful. And on August 21, 2025, a federal judge [ruled](https://newjerseyglobe.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/Brann-Habba-opinion.pdf) that indeed Habba's appointment was unlawful. The government quickly appealed, and an [expedited briefing schedule](https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.ca3.125818/gov.uscourts.ca3.125818.10.2.pdf) was set, under which the appeal should be fully briefed by October 14, 2025. But in the meantime, federal criminal trials and hearings in New Jersey are at a [standstill](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/08/28/nyregion/new-jersey-federal-court-slowdown.html), raising questions about how long the status quo can endure.

**2025 Up & Coming Attorneys: Hannah Brown, HB Law and Advocacy**
Hannah Brown, a Los Angeles native now practicing in Wayzata, has built a reputation in immigration law and wrongful‑conviction cases. In March 2025 she took on the case of Doğukan Günaydın, a Turkish national who had been arrested by ICE after a 2023 DWI conviction. Although Günaydın had paid a fine and completed probation, ICE detained him and began deportation proceedings. Brown noted, 'There are not a lot of immigration attorneys in Minnesota who represent folks who are in jail,' and she spent a day at the Sherburne County Jail to offer help. She secured a dismissal of the deportation case in immigration court, but ICE refused to release him. Brown then filed a habeas corpus petition with a federal judge. Fifty‑six days after his arrest, on May 22, U.S. District Judge Jeffrey M. Bryan signed an order stating that Günaydın’s detention violated his due‑process rights, leading to his release. Günaydın publicly thanked Brown and partner Kelsey Hines of Hines Immigration Law. Brown anticipates more cases under the Trump administration’s aggressive ICE detention policy. She also has extensive plaintiff‑side civil‑litigation experience but prioritizes immigration work, saying, 'It's a tough area for young lawyers to get into because it's not a moneymaker,' and adding, 'But we need a strong bar. We need a lot of people who are willing to fight.'

**Border apprehensions are low, but prosecutions of undocumented immigrants in San Diego are way up**
The article reports that after President Donald Trump returned to office in January 2025, the Department of Justice (DOJ) directed federal prosecutors to aggressively charge immigration‑related offenses.  According to a memo from Attorney General Pam Bondi, the DOJ would "use all available criminal statutes to combat the flood of illegal immigration that took place over the last four years."  The U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of California (SDCA) claims that this guidance has "secured the border," citing a "remarkable achievement" in reducing border apprehensions to historic lows while increasing criminal prosecutions.

CBP data show that between October 2023 and May 2024, Border Patrol agents apprehended an average of more than 33,000 single adults per month, peaking at 37,898 in April 2024.  In contrast, the SDCA filed 100 felony re‑entry cases and 27 misdemeanor illegal‑entry cases in December 2023 (Biden’s last full month), rising to 331 felony re‑entry and 155 misdemeanor cases by May 2024 under Trump‑appointed leadership.  This represents a 353 % increase in illegal‑reentry filings while apprehensions fell by 92.6 % from the same month the previous year.

The article notes that the proportion of border‑apprehended individuals charged criminally is now higher than during Trump’s first term, despite lower overall apprehensions.  Quotes from David Bier of the Cato Institute and Tom Wong of UC San Diego highlight that while prosecutions may deter some, many desperate migrants will still attempt entry.

The DOJ’s directives began with a memo from Acting Deputy Attorney General Emil Bove on Jan. 21, 2025, ordering prosecutors to "charge and pursue the most serious, readily provable offenses".  A follow‑up memo from Bondi on Feb. 5 reinforced these instructions.

Overall, the piece presents a factual overview of the shift in immigration enforcement, citing specific metrics and official statements without overt editorializing.

**Who is Lisa Cook? Meet the Fed governor Trump said he fired but is refusing to leave**
Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook, the first Black woman to sit on the Fed Board, is in the middle of a legal showdown with former President Donald Trump, who has tried to fire her.  Trump’s attempt was blocked by a federal judge, and he has asked an appeals court to allow the firing to take effect before the Fed’s policy meeting on Tuesday.  Cook was nominated by President Joe Biden in 2022 and confirmed by a 51‑47 Senate vote after Vice President Kamala Harris cast the tie‑breaking vote.  She was re‑nominated for a full term in May 2023 and reconfirmed by a 51‑47 vote.  Trump cited alleged mortgage‑fraud allegations from a letter by Federal Housing Finance Agency Director Bill Pulte as grounds for removal.  Cook’s attorneys denied the allegations and argued that the ‘for‑cause’ provision only covers conduct in office.  U.S. District Judge Jia Cobb granted a temporary block of the firing, allowing Cook to continue serving at the Fed.  The case is now pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.  Cook’s background includes a Ph.D. in economics from UC Berkeley, a Marshall Scholarship from Spelman College, and a BA from Oxford.  She has said, 'I still have scars from that -- scar where hair won't grow in my eyebrow and a scar on my leg from having been beaten during that period, during the period of desegregation,' reflecting her experience as a Black student during integration. Pam Bondi, the former Florida Attorney General who served two consecutive terms until 2019, has become a central figure in Donald Trump’s inner circle.  According to the article, Bondi first rose to national prominence in 2011 when she was elected Florida’s first woman attorney general, a state that at the time was the "capital of the opioid pill factories" with 98 of the 100 top oxycodone prescribers located there.  She later led a strict legislative effort that shut down those 98 doctors and clinics.  Bondi’s loyalty to Trump was evident during the 2016 campaign, and in February 2025 the Republican‑controlled Senate confirmed her as the U.S. Attorney General.  She promised an "independent" Department of Justice, but her first actions—such as dismantling internal structures, reversing policies, and aligning the DOJ with Trump’s wishes—were described as the "most convulsive transition in DOJ history since Watergate".

The article cites several high‑profile women in Trump’s orbit, including Ivanka Trump, Kellyanne Conway, and Megyn Kelly, to illustrate how Trump’s circle has historically "domesticated and recycled" strong women.  It quotes Susie Wiles, a long‑time Republican strategist, who said Bondi is "blonde and beautiful, but has steel nerves and has faced devastating situations with grace."  Mark Cuban is quoted as saying, "Donald Trump never surrounds himself with strong, intelligent women.  He is intimidated by them.  He does not like them to challenge him," a claim the article counters by listing Bondi’s actions.

Bondi’s tenure has been marked by a series of conservative measures: she defended Trump’s hard‑line immigration policies, limited asylum for women fleeing domestic violence, and pursued aggressive actions against transgender healthcare.  In April 2025 her DOJ issued memoranda labeling certain gender‑affirming treatments for minors as "genital mutilation" and sued states that allowed trans athletes to compete according to their gender identity.  She also appointed Alina Habba, a former Trump personal lawyer, as federal prosecutor in New Jersey.

The article details Bondi’s involvement in the Epstein case, noting her promise of a "list of many names and flight records" and her organization of a White House event titled "Epstein Files: Phase 1."  It criticizes her handling of the case, including her justification of a missing minute in the security footage as a "reset" and her alleged use of the DOJ to pursue political retribution, such as reviving the Crossfire Hurricane investigation to target former Democrats.

Overall, the piece portrays Bondi as a loyal executor of Trump’s agenda, using her position to advance conservative policies and suppress dissent, while framing her actions as a threat to democratic institutions.

Public defenders argue Chattah's term expired in July and she has been acting without 'force or effect,' seeking a court to appoint a proper interim U.S. attorney. Prosecutors counter that the court has no authority to do so, noting Chattah resigned as interim before the end of her 120‑day term. The challenge was filed in multiple criminal cases, asking courts to dismiss indictments or disqualify Chattah. Wolfson responded that Chattah had shown 'unfitness to serve' and was 'often confused and often irresponsible in her assertions.' The committee’s top Democrat, Senator Dick Durbin, cited Vance’s obstruction and the precedent set by Senator Tom Cotton. Republican Senator Charles Grassley criticized Democrats, calling the delays ‘unprecedented’ and arguing that they harm public safety. Durbin countered, noting that Republicans had broken the precedent during Trump’s first term and that 68 of Biden’s 93 nominees had been approved before the GOP blockade. Toepfer, a career prosecutor with 25 years of experience, will lead the Cleveland office for at least 120 days, after which the district’s 18 federal judges can extend his term. If not confirmed, the office would face its longest vacancy in 170 years. The last confirmed U.S. attorney, Justin Herdman, left in January 2021, and the previous nominee, Marisa Darden, resigned before assuming the role.  ‘It is the honor of a lifetime to serve the people of northern Ohio in this role,’ said Toepfer.  ‘The obstruction of U.S. Attorneys hurts our public safety,’ said Grassley.  ‘There is a conversation underway to try to find a bipartisan way out of this mess,’ said Durbin.

The U.S. Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into mortgage fraud involving Federal Reserve Board member Liza Kuk, according to Reuters. Prosecutors in the North District of Georgia and the Eastern District of Michigan are handling the case. The investigation follows former President Donald Trump’s August 25 firing of Kuk, who was accused of providing false information on mortgage applications. In a letter to Kuk, Trump said he had "sufficient grounds to remove" her, citing that in 2021 she listed two properties in Michigan and Georgia as her primary residence on loan documents. Kuk’s lawyer, Washington attorney Ebba Lowe, replied that the president has no authority to fire her and that the removal would be challenged in court. Lowe also said the president’s actions "have no legal basis." Kuk’s term on the Federal Reserve Board expires in 2038, but the law allows removal for "good cause," a provision that has never been used before. The article notes that Kuk obtained mortgage loans before her appointment to the Fed; her 2024 disclosure lists three loans, two of which were for personal residence, and the interest rates were above the national average. The move follows a pattern in which Trump‑appointed U.S. attorneys have faced judicial rejection in other districts, prompting the administration to use alternative legal mechanisms to keep its picks in place. In the Northern District of New York, for example, judges rejected John A. Sarcone III, who was then appointed as a special attorney to the attorney general to allow him to continue in the role. Similar challenges have arisen in New Jersey with Alina Habba and in other jurisdictions with Bilal “Bill” Essayli and Sigal Chattah. **The Senate faces a reality check on blue slips**
The Hill article explains why President Trump’s nominee for U.S. attorney in New Jersey, Alina Habba, has stalled: both New Jersey senators, Cory Booker and Andy Kim, refuse to return the blue‑slip that signals consent to a nomination. The piece outlines the blue‑slip tradition, a century‑old Senate Judiciary Committee practice that gives a state’s senators veto power over federal appointments in their state. It notes that in 2017, Chairman Chuck Grassley ended the blue‑slip veto for circuit‑court nominees, enabling Trump to reshape the Ninth Circuit; the article cites that this reform removed the veto power of senators from California, Hawaii, Nevada, Oregon and Washington.

The article describes how Democrats have slowed nominations in Trump’s second term, aided by a handful of Republicans who are reluctant to work. It quotes Senator Thom Tillis, who said he will not support any nominee unless the nominee’s home‑state senators return their blue slips, and notes that without Tillis Republicans lack the votes on the committee to move nominees to a floor vote. The author, Michael Zona, a former communications director for Chuck Grassley, writes that the blue‑slip rule remains "sacrosanct" to a few Republican senators and that the Senate is "behind the times." The piece concludes that unless Republicans gain a majority, the rule will persist and that the Senate should focus on working within the current system.

Key metrics and evidence: 2017 reform of the blue‑slip rule; 16 months remaining in the current Congress; 60 votes required for a discharge petition; quotes from Tillis and Zona; mention of the Ninth Circuit’s overhaul; and the statement that "I worked for Chairman Grassley" (Michael Zona).

Former Fox News host and U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro filed a quo warranto action in mid‑July seeking to have the federal court declare that President Donald Trump lawfully removed CPB board member Diane Kaplan and that Kaplan is therefore "ousted and excluded" from the board. Pirro argues that the DOJ’s earlier dismissal of claims against Laura G. Ross and Thomas E. Rothman leaves Kaplan as the sole defendant. Pirro also contends that Kaplan has attempted to maintain a position through a CPB‑created contingency plan, citing a document dated June 8 2025 that purportedly appoints a "contingent designated body" under Article V of the CPB bylaws. The court documents state that the contingency would only activate if the board fell below the statutory minimum of three directors. Pirro maintains that Kaplan is not currently serving on such a body and that the contingency plan would allow her to remain in a temporary role until the President nominates and the Senate confirms a replacement. The article notes that the CPB lawsuit, filed in April, sought an injunction against Trump’s removal of Kaplan, Rothman and Ross, but a federal judge in June dismissed the claim that Trump lacked authority to remove the board members. **Judge Rules Trump’s Former Lawyer Alina Habba Illegally Serving as New Jersey’s Chief Federal Prosecutor**
A federal judge in New Jersey ruled on August 21, 2025 that Alina Habba, who had served as President Trump’s private lawyer, was illegally acting as the state’s chief federal prosecutor since July. Judge Matthew Brann’s 77‑page decision concluded, '面对哈巴女士是否依法履行新泽西州联邦检察官职务的问题，我的结论是否定的。', and stated that because she lacks the authority to exercise the office, she must be barred from any ongoing cases. The ruling also declared that any prosecutions conducted under her supervision are invalid from July 1, 2025, though the judge will not enforce the order until a higher court reviews it, allowing Habba to remain in her position temporarily.

President Trump appointed Habba as interim U.S. attorney in March 2024 for a 120‑day term. When that term expired in July, the district judge appointed her deputy Desiree Grace as successor, but the Department of Justice immediately fired Grace and reappointed Habba as a "Special Attorney to the Attorney General." Under federal law, an interim attorney’s term ends unless the judge appoints a new interim or the Senate confirms a nominee; Habba’s case is the only one currently litigated for violating this rule.

Three criminal defendants in New Jersey sued, arguing that Habba had no authority to prosecute them after July and sought to have their charges dismissed. Judge Brann agreed that Habba lacked authority but refused to dismiss the charges, instead invalidating any actions taken under her supervision. The DOJ maintains that the President has broad discretion to appoint attorneys, asserting, '总统已明确指出，除哈巴外，不允许任何人以临时身份填补美国检察官办公室的现有空缺。' Pam Bondi, the U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey, announced she would appeal the ruling and posted on X, '（哈巴）在新泽西的工作非常出色 -- -- 我们将保护她的职位，免受司法激进派的攻击。'

Habba has also investigated New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy’s immigration policy, though no charges have yet been filed.

Brann said, 'Faced with the question of whether Ms. Habba is lawfully performing the functions and duties of the office of the United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey, I conclude that she is not.' **Former Trump attorney Alina Habba is serving unlawfully as New Jersey's top federal prosecutor, judge rules**
U.S. District Judge Matthew Brann of Pennsylvania ruled that former President Trump lawyer Alina Habba has been serving as the U.S. attorney for New Jersey without lawful authority since July 1, 2025, and must be disqualified from supervising any ongoing cases. The judge’s decision followed challenges by three men facing criminal charges—two charged with drug offenses and one with investment fraud and bribery—who argued that Habba’s appointment as acting U.S. attorney violated the Federal Vacancies Reform Act. Brann wrote, 'Faced with the question of whether Ms. Habba is lawfully performing the functions and duties of the office of the United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey, I conclude that she is not,' and added that she has served unlawfully since July 1. The ruling does not invalidate the indictments of the three defendants, but it bars Habba from supervising their prosecutions and is on hold pending a possible appeal by the Justice Department. Earlier this year, Habba was named interim U.S. attorney, a role limited to 120 days unless extended by the district court or confirmed by the Senate; New Jersey senators Cory Booker and Andy Kim opposed her nomination. When the 120‑day limit approached, district court judges installed her second‑in‑command, Desiree Leigh Grace, as acting prosecutor, but Attorney General Pam Bondi subsequently fired Grace. To circumvent the judge’s order, President Trump withdrew Habba’s nomination to serve as the top federal prosecutor, allowing her to remain in an acting capacity until the court’s order. Brann emphasized that the Trump administration could only appoint an interim U.S. attorney for 120 days, a clock that began in early March when Habba’s predecessor was appointed, not in late March when Habba assumed the role. He also struck down the Justice Department’s attempt to label her a 'special attorney', stating that without the official title she cannot perform the duties of U.S. attorney.

summary:
Across a diverse panel of experts—including specialists in federal legal practice, US government affairs, public administration, political science, and law—the overwhelming consensus is that Alina Habba is unlikely to remain the U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey on December 31, 2025. All forecasters highlighted the following core points:

1. The legal basis for Habba's appointment is extremely weak after a federal court ruled her service unlawful. This creates strong headwinds for her continued tenure, and base rates for similar situations suggest removal is the most likely outcome.

2. The Trump administration and Attorney General Pam Bondi have demonstrated determination to keep Habba in place through creative statutory maneuvers and persistent resistance to judicial rulings, which marginally increases her chances of remaining temporarily.

3. The expedited appeals process—scheduled to conclude well before the resolution date—means a final judicial outcome is likely by year's end. Experts believe the judiciary's assertiveness and strong statutory foundation make a successful defense of Habba’s position on appeal unlikely.

4. Senate obstruction and blue-slip traditions make a regular, confirmed replacement unlikely, but this does not significantly improve Habba’s odds given the legal challenges and court authority to appoint a replacement.

5. The practical standstill in federal criminal prosecutions in New Jersey adds pressure for a resolution, making indefinite legal limbo unsustainable.

6. The official U.S. Attorney’s Office website will serve as the tiebreaker; some experts noted a residual chance that bureaucratic inertia or further legal wrangling could delay an update past December 31, but this is considered improbable.

Probabilities assigned by individual experts ranged from 10%-20% for Habba remaining in office through the resolution date, with only one outlier at 30%. All group discussions converged on the expectation that the judiciary will prevail in removing her, and that the unique willingness of the Trump administration to defy legal norms does not fully offset the statutory and judicial obstacles. The scenario described by all as most probable is the appeals court upholding the district court’s decision, followed by Habba’s removal and the office’s website reflecting a new head before year’s end.

In summary, while there remains a slim chance of continued executive defiance or procedural delay, the consensus is that legal, institutional, and operational factors make it highly unlikely that Alina Habba will be U.S. Attorney for New Jersey on December 31, 2025.
